comments.comment: <font >I won't call it "fairly large". Sure, some differences exist because of the culture and the size of the country. And I'm not considering divisive politicians when I say this.</font>

http://hntrends.jerodsanto.net/?q=ruby%2Cpython

http://hntrends.jerodsanto.net/?q=rails%2Cdjango

Interesting that Ruby stays below Python but Rails stays well above Django.

children.comment: <font >There are similar metrics for job openings. It seems plausible that Python is becoming an all-purpose language while the focus for Rails / Ruby is on web apps. If true, this would be reminiscent of Perl v. PHP.</font>

comments.comment: <font >Society definitely plays a role. Working in "some little, unknown company" (a startup) is hard to explain to people with little or no knowledge of what we do. Being an entrepreneur is worse: you are considered "insane" if you quit a well paying job to start a company.</font>

This is why I built "GitHub Feed Filter" - a Google Chrome extension (https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/jcpkhafkpnaljjbgdg...). It adds an interface in the page that enables users to look at feeds filtered by projects, by commits, by issues and by comments.

children.comment: <font >Awesome!! Going to install this right now.</font>
<font >Thanks. Will appreciate any feedback to improve.</font>

comments.comment:
Adding a couple of ? at the end and re-submitting a story that is still on the first page (#17 right now) is not cool.

I understand that there is an update on the story, but is re-submitting the only way to convey that to HN? Not quite sure.
<font >Please be nice when pointing out mistakes. Not everyone is a native English speaker here.</font>

A few niceties:

1. Console shows SQL queries right there.

2. The file_field automatically adds :multipart => true to the enclosing form.

3. Newer Migrations - There is a "change" method now which can be used to write only the "up" part of the migration and Rails will automatically reverse when a migration is rolled back.
